conclusion: Analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D change when light source moves backward
Decorative bird cage with shadow A
Shadow B appears to be cast by the same object as A from a different angle
Wall lamp with shadow C
Decorative cross or sword with shadow D
Light source illuminating objects, creating shadows on stone slab floor
Principles of shadow behavior when light source moves backward
Shadow size increases when light source moves backward
Shadow position moves further from the object when light source moves backward
Shadow edges become less defined/more blurry when light source moves backward
Shadow A is relatively sharp and positioned directly beneath/beside the bird cage
Shadow A will enlarge, move further away, and edges become less defined when light moves backward
Shadow B is another shadow from the bird cage from a different angle
Shadow B will grow larger, extend further, and edges become less distinct when light moves backward
Shadow C is fairly defined from the lamp
Shadow C will increase in size, extend further, and become less sharp when light moves backward
Shadow D is a defined shadow from the decorative item
Shadow D will enlarge, move further, and boundaries become more diffuse when light moves backward
All shadows will increase in size, move further away, and edges become less defined when light source moves backward
Relative positions of shadows remain the same but expand outward when light source moves backward
Light rays hit objects at a wider angle causing shadows to elongate and grow larger
